newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Poll finds Colombia lawman most popular politician.
newsitem.headline: Poll finds Colombia lawman most popular politician.

text.p: Colombia's chief prosecutor, Alfonso Valdivieso, a crusader against narcotics and official corruption, is the country's most popular politician, according to a poll published Thursday.
In a survey by the respected El Espectador newspaper, 33 percent of those asked said they would vote for Valdivieso if presidential elections were held tomorrow.
Interior Minister Horacio Serpa, seen by many as President Ernesto Samper's natural heir, mustered only 17 percent support in the poll. The next presidential elections are due in 1998.

Valdivieso, regarded here as a U.S. favourite, has made enemies at home for his fight against corruption, which has included investigating allegations that Samper financed his 1994 election campaign with drug money.
On a visit to Miami last week, Valdivieso said he would score Samper's presidency with about three out of 10.

Noemi Sanin, a Conservative Party member and former ambassador to Britain, scored 18 percent in the poll. Alvaro Uribe, the hardline governor of the northwestern province of Antioquia, was backed by 5 percent of respondents.
The survey of 1,000 people was conducted jointly by El Espectador and the CM& television news programme on Dec. 9 and 10 and has a margin of error of 3.1 percent.
